did.head: Collection Overview
did.unittitle: June in Buffalo Papers, 1975-1977, 1980

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: State University of New York at Buffalo. Music Library

did.abstract: The June in Buffalo Papers consist of administrative papers created to run the music festival that ran 1975-1978, and 1980 at the State University of New York at Buffalo and clippings about the concerts.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Specified item], June in Buffalo Papers, 1975-1977, 1980, Music Library, The State University of New York at Buffalo.

accessrestrict.head: Terms of Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials can be examined by qualified researchers in the Music Library during hours of operation during which Music Librarians are present. In order to insure access, researchers are advised to contact the Music Library in advance of visits.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: Copyright for the materials in the collection does not reside with the Music Library. Therefore, patrons wishing to publish any item, or part of an item from this collection for any purpose, are responsible for securing requisite permissions.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Originally received with Morton Feldman Papers, which were a gift of Barbara Monk Feldman in 1992.

accruals.head: Accruals and Additions
accruals.p: No further accruals are expected to this collection.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The June in Buffalo festival of contemporary music was established by Morton Feldman in 1975. Morton Feldman joined the University at Buffalo Music Faculty in 1972. He was the Slee Professor, 1972-1973, Edgar Varèse Professor, 1975-1987, and the Director of the Center of the Creative and Performing Arts, 1976-1980. Feldman established the June in Buffalo festival in 1975 as a counterpart to the Center of the Creative and Performing Arts' successful Evenings for New Music concerts. The new festival was presented 1975-1978, and again in 1980, with a year off in 1979 when Feldman was on sabbatical. The festival was revived in 1986 by composer David Felder and is still in operation as of this writing (2015). Although the two festivals share the same name it is convenient to consider them as two separate entities.

In addition to presenting concerts, Feldman's festival created a seminar environment in which student composers attended workshops where distinguished composers-in-residence rehearsed their works and gave lectures. Feldman also wanted to create a more intense listening experience by presenting programs that contained multiple works by a single composer. To that end, twelve works by John Cage were presented on the three concerts that opened the first festival in June 1975. Other single-composer programs were devoted to the works of Christian Wolff, Ralph Shapey, George Crumb, Lejaren Hiller, Nils Vigeland, Steve Reich, Charles Wuorinen, Henry Brant, Elliott Carter, Stefan Wolpe, Milton Babbitt, Lou Harrison, Earle Brown, and Aaron Copland. Works by earlier twentieth-century composers, including Ives, Schoenberg, Satie, Cowell, Webern, Berg, and Bártók were also presented on June in Buffalo programs. Three works received their United States premieres and five works received their world premieres at the festival. All concerts but one were held in what was then called Baird Hall (now Allen Hall) on what is now the South Campus of the University at Buffalo. The June 1, 1976 concert was held at the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The June in Buffalo Papers consist of administrative papers created to run the music festival at the State University of New York at Buffalo, including schedules, budgets, correspondence, programs and publicity materials, as well as clippings about the concerts. The records are incomplete, containing content for 1975, 1976, 1977, and 1980, but none for 1978.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in four series for each of the four years of records held. Materials are categorized by the year of the festival to which they pertain not necessarily by the date of creation. However, the date of creation is stated in the inventory. Concert reviews are organized by date of the concert reviewed, not by publication date. The series are subdivided when appropriate by subseries for Administrative papers, including budgetary documents, Publicity and Programs, Correspondence, and Clippings.

did.unittitle: June in Buffalo papers, 1975

arrangement.p:
Arranged into subseries for:
I.A Administrative papers
I.B Correspondence
I.C Clippings

did.unittitle: Administrative papers 1975
Typescript note from Renée Levine and Jan Williams to Morton Feldman and Lejaren Hiller with performance budget, April 25, 1975
Correspondence, 1974-1975
Letter from Sylvia Brigham-Dimiziani to Christian Wolff, November 13, 1974
Letter from John Duffy (for Meet the Composer) to Morton Feldman, April 28, 1975
Letter from Mimi Johnson (for John Cage) to Sylvia Brigham-Dimiziani, November 4, 1974
Clippings, 1975

arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically by the date of the concert (not the date of publication of the review).

did.unittitle: Administrative papers 1980
Schedules, expenses, and handwritten notes about June in Buffalo, 1980
Correspondence, 1980
Five letters from John Duffy (for Meet the Composer) to Morton Feldman, January 31, 1980, February 1, 1980

note.p: The letters concern appearances at June in Buffalo 1980 by composers George Crumb, Steve Reich, Ralph Shapey, Christian Wolff, and Charles Wuorinen. Each letter is accompanied by a contract.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Resources in the Music Library

defitem.label: Recordings of June in Buffalo, 1975-1978, 1980 Mus. Arc. 30
defitem.item: The collection contains recordings of fifty-one of the fifty-three concerts presented at the previous hit June in Buffalo next hit festival from 1975-1978 and in 1980. Approximately 216 works were recorded as well as some spoken introductions to works by their respective composers.
